name: amsynth
label: amsynth
comment:
The AmSynth is a synth with a classic subtractive synthesizer topology. It features Dual oscillators, a resonant filter, a dual ADSR and a LFO. If you’re not into turning a bunch of fancy knobs and just want to plug and play, give the presets of this synth a go, it has a broad variety of sounds including some classic synths and some funky noises!

Features:
Modeled by Nick Dowell

name: Instrument Tuner
label: Tuna Tuner
comment: Musical instrument tuner with strobe characteristics

name: Neural Amp Modeler
label: Neural Amp Modeler
comment:
The Neural Amp Modeler (NAM) is an open-source guitar software plugin that creates realistic simulations of analog gear, especially guitar amplifiers.
The plugin utilizes neural amp modeling technology, which employs neural networks and machine learning algorithms to replicate the behavior and characteristics of real amplifiers.

NAM loads *.nam files, enabling users to access a vast collection of meticulously crafted amp and pedal models.

You can discover a wide range of authentic tones, from vintage classics to modern designs at https://tonehunt.org/?tags=nano-mdl with their extensive library of nam models.
For MOD units search for the models with the #nano-mdl tag, as heavier models might not work.

NAM was created by Steven Ack and the LV2 version is maintained by Mike Oliphant.

name: GxAmplifier-X
label: GxAmplifier
comment:
The GxAmplifier-X is a do-it-all amplifier simulator based on some of the most famous tube amplifiers such as Fender, Mesa, Soldano, Vox and Marshall models. The ability to switch preamp and power amp tubes makes it an even more versatile amp. The built-in cabinet simulation eliminates the need of an additional cabinet simulator. Whether you are looking for a Fenderish sound, or a metal sound straight out of the eighties, the Gx-Amplifier-X will fulfill all your needs. 

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix

name: GxCabinet
label: GxCabinet
comment:
The GxCabinet is based on emulations of famous cabinet models ranging from more classic vintage sounding to modern, cleaner tones.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix

name: GxFlanger
label: GxFlanger
comment:
"Flanging /ˈflændʒɪŋ/ is an audio effect produced by mixing two identical signals together, one signal delayed by a small and gradually changing period, usually smaller than 20 milliseconds. This produces a swept comb filter effect: peaks and notches are produced in the resulting frequency spectrum, related to each other in a linear harmonic series. Varying the time delay causes these to sweep up and down the frequency spectrum. A flanger is an effects unit that creates this effect.

Part of the output signal is usually fed back to the input (a "re-circulating delay line"), producing a resonance effect which further enhances the intensity of the peaks and troughs. The phase of the fed-back signal is sometimes inverted, producing another variation on the flanging sound." Wikipedia

*Unofficial documentation

source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flanging

name: GxFuzz
label: GxFuzz
comment:
A fuzz effect with lots of volume

*Unofficial documentation

name: GxAlembic
label: GxAlembic
comment:
The Alembic is inspired by the Alembic F-2B© studio preamp (*).

The Alembic appeared in the late 60’s and was inspired by the circuit on the Fender Dual Showman© (*) amps, which were known for their deep and clean powerful tone. This legend featured a 12AX7 tube in each section and was widely used for both bass and guitar.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix

(*) ”Other product names modeled in the software trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. Alembic F-2B© preamp and Fender Dual Showman© are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of the product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: GxTubeScreamer
label: GxTubeScreamer
comment:
The GxTubeScreamer is an analog distortion emulation of the classic Ibanez TS-9© (*).

First released in 1982 this is a real classic among all musicians. The pedal mimics the sound of a vintage tube amplifier, and has a characteristic mid-boosted tone which is popular amongst blues and rock players. The legendary Tube Screamer has been used by countless guitarists to create their signature sound, and is one of the most successful, widely copied and "modded" overdrive pedals in the history of the electric guitar.

It has a drive knob, a tone knob, and a level knob. The drive knob adjusts gain, the tone knob adjusts treble and the level knob adjusts the output volume of the pedal.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
Ibanez TS-9© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

comment:
The Chief Executive Oscillator forever calls for more profit.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Compress - Mono compressor
label: Compress
comment:
This compressor has been designed primarily to create natural-sounding sustain for the electric guitar without sacrificing its brightly percussive character. However, it appears to apply well to a variety of other sound sources, and with CompressX2 a stereo version is available as well.

To be able produce strong compression and still maintain a natural sound, the design catches (attack-phase) power spikes with a soft saturation circuit, converting them into additional harmonic content and enforcing a strict limit on the output level. Saturating operation is the default setting of the mode control. Three anti-aliasing options are available, 2x oversampling with 32-tap filters and 4x with 64 and 128 taps.

The measure control select which indicator of loudness to base calculations on: peak – instantaneous amplitude – measurement allows the unit to react very quickly, while rms – root mean square power – is of a gentler kind.

Compression amount is controlled through the strength knob, from 0 effectively disabling the effect, up to a maximum ratio of 16:1. The attack and release controls map higher values to slower reactions.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Wider - Stereo image Synthesis
label: Wider
comment:
Wider increases the width of a signal.
In addition to providing a basic panorama control, a perception of stereo width is created using complementary filters on the two outputs.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS
Based on the Orban 245F Stereo Synthesizer© (*)

(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
The Orban 245F Stereo Synthesizer© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: DS1
label: DS1
comment:
The DS1 is modeled after the legendary BOSS DS-1(*), a distortion pedal mainly used for guitar.

Simply put, the DS1 distortion pedal is a modern classic. It was first produced in 1978 and is still widely popular. No wonder it was part of pedalboards from great names such as Kurt Cobain, Joe Satriani, Steve Vai and Josh Klinghoffer.

The DS1 features three knobs which can take the sound in a variety of different directions. By cranking up its tone levels and distortion knobs, you can pull out a range of different tones, from subtle bite to rich crunch to all-out fuzz. The midrange on the DS1 is scooped, giving it a distinct tonal flavor, which many players prefer. Want sonic reference? Give Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" a listen - all that crunch came courtesy of a DS1.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices
Based on the classic BOSS DS-1(*)

(*) 'Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
BOSS DS-1 is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.'

name: Drop
label: Drop
comment:
Drop is a pitch-shifter that can drop the pitch to a maximum of -12 semitones (steps). Have more control over your processing power by adjusting the fidelity of the plugin. A lower fidelity means a less pristine sound, but less processing power and vice-versa.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Gain 2x2
label: Gain 2x2
comment:
A simple stereo volume gain plugin without "zipping" noise when messing around with the gain parameter.
Also available in a mono version. 

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Noise Gate
label: Noise Gate
comment:
The MOD Noise Gate is a streamlined, easy-to-use Noise Gate plugin which can also be found in the MOD Dwarf's and Duox's input processing settings.

There is a parameter to set which channel to apply the noise gate to: none, channel 1, channel 2 or stereo.
There is also a threshold parameter, and a decay time parameter.
For more in depth control, try the MOD Noise Gate Advanced plugin.

Features:
Modeled by VeJa Plugins
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Bollie Delay
label: Bollie Delay
comment:
The Bollie Delay is a stereo tempo delay featuring high pass and low pass filter as well as a host tempo function, granting more control over your delay settings. This powerful delay is perfect for experimenting with your vocals or your guitar. 

Features:
Modeled by Bollie

name: Pitchotto
label: Pitchotto
comment:
Pitchotto is a pitch-shifter based on the "Pitch-Shift"-genpatch in Max, where Phase-shifting is used to achieve different intervals.
There are two shifted signals available, both with variable delay-lengths for arpeggio-like sounds.
